name: DEPUTY SPEAKER, The
content: Im pleased to rise on behalf of my community in support of the Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024. This might be hard for the member for Wannon to hear, but every taxpayer in Australia will be better off under Labors tax reform. Labor will deliver a tax cut to every single taxpayer in this country, including every taxpayer in the member for Wannons electorate and every single taxpayer in the electorate of Dobell on the New South Wales Central Coast, which I represent. Whether its the waiter living in Wyong or the nurse in Narara or the tradie in Toukley, each will receive a tax cut under Labors reforms.  We want people to earn more and keep more of what they earn. In real terms these tax reforms will mean a retail worker earning $45,000 will get a tax cut of $804. A teacher—and I note a former principal is in the chamber at the moment—earning $80,000 will get a tax cut of $1,679. An electrician earning $110,000 will get a tax cut of $2,429. This is real costofliving relief. Importantly, in my community of Dobell, on the north end of the Central Coast of New South Wales, 88 per cent of taxpayers will be better off under Labors tax plan than under the plan legislated by the previous Liberal Morrison government. If wed kept in place the stage 3 plan legislated by the previous Liberal government many people in my community would not be receiving a tax cut at all. We know a lot of people are doing it tough right now in my community on the Central Coast and right around Australia, and I see that in the communities I have the privilege of visiting with my responsibilities as Assistant Minister for Rural and Regional Health. But, as the Prime Minister said in his address to the National Press Club—and I was pleased to be there to hear the Prime Minister being open and upfront about his plan: Our job isnt to say Ill just wring my hands about the costofliving pressures that people are feeling. Our job is to respond, to seek advice and then to make a difference, to make the right decision not the easy decision. Thats what the Prime Minister has done; thats what Prime Minister Albanese has done. Thats what our Labor government is doing. Thats why were making these changes, changes that will deliver meaningful costofliving relief for people on the Central Coast and right around the country. Labors tax reforms will deliver bigger tax cuts for low and middleincome earners, significantly helping with the cost of living and taking pressure off household and family budgets. Take a nurse at Wyong Hospital, where I used to work. Theyve recently received a pay increase through the work of the New South Wales Labor government and my union, the Health Services Union. Now that nurse will be able to keep more of what shes earning. That nurse, earning $76,000, will receive a tax cut of $1,579. These are the frontline workers of the pandemic. They deserve more than our thanks. Under Labor, at both the New South Wales and the federal level, those frontline healthcare workers will be earning more and, importantly, keeping more of what theyre earning. Ive heard from many people across the coast who have expressed their support for these tax changes, because from 1 July they will help ease the cost of living for them, for their family members and for people in our community. Take Kerrilyn from Woongarrah, who said: I think considering the economic climate and the amount of people struggling, implementing tax cuts for the wealthy who are not struggling is a bad plan. We need money to support the vulnerable and to help them with the cost of living. In particular our young people, who often are studying or earning low wages. This is the view of Kerrilyn from Woongarrah, and its a view that I know many people in this chamber share. Bronwyn from Toukley contacted my office and said: I am delighted to see that the Stage 3 tax cuts previously legislated have been modified. I would have been a major recipient of the top end cut, and I would much rather those on lower incomes get the bulk of the cuts. It is good to see the government taking this approach. I was at a community festival, the Love Lanes Festival, in my hometown of Wyong on the weekend, and Mark from Mardi came up to me just to let me know what he thought of Labors tax reform. He said: The tax savings under the changes now legislated by the government will have a bigger impact on all important economic growth. And this is his field. This is the field he works in. He went on to say: This combined with the wellestablished Australian principle of fairness makes the proposed changes good economic & social policy. That was Mark from Mardi, who I know from working as a volunteer director at a local community bank. I support this legislation, and, importantly, my community supports this legislation—Kerrilyn from Woongarrah, Bronwyn from Toukley, Mark from Mardi and so many others who have told me personally or contacted my office. Its important to note that, alongside these tax cuts, were delivering further costofliving relief by lifting the threshold for the Medicare levy, offering tax relief to lowincome earners. These important tax reforms join a list of Labor reforms supporting fairness, equity and aspiration for all Australians. In a year and a half of government, weve shown genuine economic leadership, bringing the budget back into surplus, easing costofliving pressures and investing in health, housing and education. This is important reform, easing the cost of living and helping to take pressure off inflation, which were pleased to see is moderating. However, as the Treasurer said, we understand there is more to do. Many Australians are under the pump right now, including in my community, and we are determined to do more. As the Prime Minister said, he wont sit by and wring his hands when he has the power to make a real difference for Australians. In conclusion, this legislation means all 13.6 million taxpayers will receive a tax cut from 1 July. Eightyfour per cent of taxpayers will receive a bigger tax cut. Eightyeight per cent of taxpayers in my electorate will receive a bigger tax cut. This plan is better for women. Its better for taxpayers. Its better for all Australians.   This is quite a complicated package. Ill get to the slice and dice in a minute, but I think that the people listening to this broadcast and the Australian people need to know the truth, and the truth is that this package is not a tax cut; it is a tax increase. The whole package increases the tax take by this Labor government by $28 billion over the next 10 years. It is not a reduction in taxes for the Australian people; it is an increase. It is in the Labor Partys DNA. They are increasing taxes. This is not a decrease; this is an increase—$28 billion onto the bottom line.  Lets look at how this has come about. The commitment to the stage 3 tax cuts was made in previous term by those opposite when they were in opposition. They remained committed to them throughout the last election. In fact, they remained committed to them up until a couple of weeks ago. Lets look at some of those statements. On 29 August 2022, in his 100 days in government speech at the National Press Club, the Prime Minister was asked about the stage 3 tax cuts by Andrew Probyn, who was then with the ABC—and we all know what happened there. The answer from Mr Albanese was quite straightforward: Parliament made a decision to legislate those tax cuts, and we made a decision that we would stand by that legislation rather than relitigate it, and we havent changed our opinion. That was just in August. In fact, it was only a few weeks ago that it was committed to again and again and again and again and again. In fact, it was committed to more than a hundred times! If we look at what else those opposite misled the Australian people on at the last election, theres quite a list. The Prime Minister committed that they would lower the cost of living. I know the people I represent dont think the cost of living is lower. They think its extraordinarily high. Im sure its the same, Deputy Speaker Buchholz, for the people that you represent. In fact, the average individual is paying $8,000 a year more than they were, and if you have a mortgage then your costs are between $20,000 and $30,000 a year more. Thats $20,000 to $30,000 on top of the other costs. We all remember the Prime Minister waving the dollar coin, the fabulous dollar coin. Well, that dollar coin under this Labor government is worth far less now than when the Prime Minister—the Leader of the Opposition at the time—was waving it around at a press conference. It is extraordinary how much real wages have fallen. It is incredibly expensive. I note the contribution from the member for Wannon. The member for Wannon spoke extensively about the commitment to reduce electricity prices by $275. Well, I can tell you whos getting that reduction right now, and thats the people of Victoria, because 500,000 of them arent connected to electricity. Theyre having an enormous blackout in Victoria as a result of a very poor state Labor government. The $275 is not to be seen. So those opposite failed to lower the cost of living, they failed to reduce the cost of mortgages and they failed to reduce power prices. In fact, all of those things have increased. They also made some commitments to not change some things. They committed to not changing franking credits—broken. They committed to no changes to superannuation—broken. Theyve also committed to no changes to negative gearing. In fact, the Treasurer spoke about it during the last couple of days. They have no plans to change negative gearing, no plans whatsoever. Well, we dont have to look too far back to see where those plans might have been. We dont have to look far at all. If you look back to 8 February, theres a headline in the Australian from Rosie Lewis, Next go get negative gearing, ALP told. Go and get negative gearing. How long would it take to work up that policy for those in government? Well, it wont take long, because its already done. It was done in the 2019 campaign when the opposition leader was Mr Shorten, the member for Maribyrnong. In fact, the Parliamentary Budget Office costed those changes. Its already costed. It was Labor policy. And what would the impact be? An increase in the tax take of almost $3 billion a year. So we see a package here of tax increases worth almost $28 billion over the next 10 years. Then theres negative gearing, which those opposite have committed to not change: Its not our policy. Our position hasnt changed. Im confident weve heard that many, many times before. The cost of that would be another $3 billion, potentially—in fact, probably even more—out of the Australian peoples pockets. This government is a typical highspending, hightaxing Labor government. And that is before we get anywhere near the family home or death duties. We currently have an appointment to the Productivity Commission, made by the Treasurer, of an individual who, just weeks—in fact, days—before they took up that position, called for death duties to be put in place in this country. It would be a massive increase in the tax take. It would be another broken commitment to the Australian people, on top of not lowering the cost of living, on top of not lowering mortgage repayments, on top of no $275 reduction in power prices, on top of saying no changes to franking credits—but they did—and on top of saying no changes to superannuation—but they did. Weve got a Treasurer who is now claiming the changes in the Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024 are some sort of miracle for those who are on a lower income scale, yet it was this Treasurer that refused to give them the low and middleincome tax offset. Thats worth up to $1,500. I couldnt tell you how many people in my electorate came up to me and said: Our tax return this year is terrible. We were banking on that money to pay our credit card, to help pay our electricity bill and to assist with our mortgage and our school fees—all the things that we have to pay for. Now we see commitments of likely around $900, as a comparison, and the Treasurer wants someone to pin a medal on his chest and give him a round of applause, a standing ovation. They have returned less in this package than what those individuals were getting from the low and mediumincome tax offset by a substantial amount of money. But you dont have to listen to me, you dont have to believe what I say. We could go to a piece by an individual by the name of Cameron Milner, who Im led to believe was a former secretary of the Labor Party in Queensland. Mr Milner had an oped, an opinion piece, in the Australian on 13 February 2024. The headline says Albanese has to revert to true Labor policies he once backed with an opening paragraph of: At long last, the Albanese government can start being a Labor government. The broken promise on tax cuts … Well, that is exactly what Labor governments do. They break their promises; they increase taxes; they spend more. This government has spent an extraordinary amount of money. They had buckets of gold coming in from the resources sector and record levels of exports—$460 billion in a year. Its an incredible amount of wealth coming into the Australian economy, coming into the tax take for this government, and what do they do? They spent most of it. And now they want to claim that this bill reduces taxes. No matter how you slice and dice it, it is an increase in taxes to the Australian people. In fact, if youre on the higher end, youre getting a tax increase compared to where it is currently legislated. Youre going to pay more tax than is currently legislated. That is just a statement of fact. Another piece in this oped by Mr Milner says: For all the damage done, the $15 a week is calculated by economists to be about onetenth of the increase in the cost of living for people under the last 18 months of the Albanese government. Fifteen dollars a week is not 10 per cent of the increase in costs—not 10 per cent. So, if the individuals in Dunkley, for example, are listening, you have a 90 per cent increase that is not offset by these changes, assuming that you are at work, of course, and youre earning in those brackets—$15 a week. The other piece which is quite interesting in this opinion piece—and its one of the reasons I raised it—is this: Mr Albaneses relationship with the Treasurer, according to Mr Milner, is by all accounts shredded after last week. And allegedly Chalmers told colleagues of the broken promise—and this is a quote: Tails, I win. Heads, he loses. This is Australias Treasurer talking about Australias Prime Minister. This is about the ambitions of the Treasurer. Its not about the Australian people; its about what damage he can do to the Prime Minister in his own party, in his own government. Weve heard a lot this week about an ABC program called Nemesis. Well, Id suggest to the Prime Minister that he might want to get a Tshirt printed, and he might want to get the Treasurer to wear it so he can identify where his nemesis is, because he is right behind him! When were in here for question time and the Prime Minister is at the dispatch box, nemesis is behind him. It is the Treasurer, whose ambition knows absolutely no bounds. It is quite an extraordinary thing to have quoted. Can you imagine where this came from? Clearly, it was provided. Clearly, it was briefed. Clearly, it was given to the individual to use as a quote in this story. At long last, the Albanese government can start being a Labor government. We look forward to those changes for every single Australian that is out there and that has worked hard to build their wealth. We keep hearing these comparisons between the current generation and the older generation and about how the older generation has more wealth. Theyve worked for an extra three or four decades; thats how you build wealth. You work hard, you make decisions and you dont spend your money on things which dont help you. In fact, you make tough decisions. You might not take a holiday. You might not go overseas. You might not get a new car, because you want to build wealth for you and your family. As you get older, that is what happens. Its no surprise to me that the older generations have more wealth than the younger generations, because theyve been alive longer, they have worked hard for a long time, it is their wealth, they deserve it, and they should do what they want with their money. It is their money. But this government want to take wealth from the people who have earned it and give it to others who want it. That is their plan. That is the program. It is the distribution of wealth from those who have it to those who do not. I come back to where I started. This package is, in total, a taxtake increase. For those individuals who have ambition and want to move forward, like teachers who might want to be a head of department or a principal, or those who might want to be a nursing unit manager or a sergeant of police, or those who want to advance themselves and do extra study, work hard and take that opportunity, the package put forward by this Labor government means they will pay significantly more tax than they would under the current legislation. Every single time they do more work, work harder and push themselves into the next bracket, they will pay more tax. Theyre out doing extra shifts, working flyin, flyout, working drivein, driveout, and theyre away from their family for weeks or months—a long time—because they make a commitment to do everything they can to look after their family and to give them the things that they might not have had when they were younger. They work to give them an education, a roof over their head and an opportunity to go and do what they want. This Labor government dont support that ambition at all. They think that those who have earned the wealth dont deserve it and shouldnt keep it and that it should be taken from them and given to others, and that is what we see with all of these broken promises. There are broken promises to lower the cost of living, broken promises to lower mortgage repayments, broken promises on power prices, broken promises on franking credits and broken promises on no changes to superannuation. It is a broken record. This Labor government, when the election comes, will be caught out, and theyll— Mr McCormack: Theyll stand condemned. Mr PITT: Stand condemned, says the member for Riverina. What a fantastic line. The Australian people know whats going out of their accounts. They know what its costing them every single week. They know how much it costs for food and fuel. They know their repayments are through the roof. There are any number of working people who are now homeless. Theyre living in their cars, in tents and in caravans. I have lived in my region most of my life, and I have never seen a situation like I see right now. The idea that those opposite will give $15 a week—just 10 per cent of the increase in costs—is a disgrace. It does not help them, it doesnt deliver what they need, and every single one of them knows it. At the next election, I will guarantee that, no matter what they say, you cannot believe those opposite. Who do you trust? It is not the Labor government.
subdebateinfo: Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024, Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living—Medicare Levy) Bill 2024
Speaker: Ms McBRIDE (Dobell—Assistant Minister for Mental Health and Suicide Prevention and Assistant Minister for Rural and Regional Health)

name: McCormack, Michael MP
content: N/A
subdebateinfo: Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024, Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living—Medicare Levy) Bill 2024
Speaker: N/A

name: McCormack, Michael MP
content: Ninetyone per cent of taxpayers in Spence will be better off under our plan, the Albanese Labor government plan, compared to the previous Morrison government plan—that is, 67,000 people of the 74,000 taxpayers will be better off under our plan. These 67,000 people across Spence will enjoy an average tax cut of $1,217 a year. This is a redistribution that will deliver tax cuts to those who need it most. Even then, like all Australians, the remaining 7,000 will still receive a tax cut under our plan, because our government is delivering bigger, better and fairer tax cuts to the people of Spence.  Despite these benefits, not just to my electorate but to 84 per cent of taxpayers nationwide, there is opposition in the form of the opposition. Much of their recent discourse has been about a lack of aspiration. It is a shame that those opposite imply that 91 per cent of taxpayers in Spence apparently arent aspiring to bigger and better things just because they are receiving a bigger tax cut. It is offensive. Speaking as one of the now fewer than 667 residents in Spence who owns well over the bracket our changes are aimed towards, I can say I am proud to be part of a government which adjusts policy to meet the needs of the people it represents. At a time when we need positivity, all we hear from those opposite is negative, negative, negative. Instead, our government is one that listens to those it represents and adapts to change where it is needed, and, because of this, we are delivering bigger, better and fairer tax cuts for all of Australia. However, despite these bigger, better and fairer tax cuts, it was kneejerk horror from those opposite. We had a deputy leader of the opposition vow to roll them back before these changes had even been proposed, such is the vehement disdain for the working people of Spence and beyond. We also had the Leader of the Opposition call for an election on the matter, so disturbed that the working people of this country be offered a better deal when they need it most. And then on Sky News, 25 January this year, Senator Hanson proclaimed: I was wanting my cuts. I would rather put the money in my pocket. Indeed, she believes: The lowerclass Australians, the ones who are not on high wages, they have plus, plus, plus. I have had a gutful. Lowerclass Australians? Really? Shame on Senator Hanson for attacking those across the country, the 91 per cent in my electorate of Spence who will be better off under our plan as if they are putting a hole in her pocket. Fortunately, those I mentioned have since come to their senses and backflipped to support our plan. If you are a factory worker in my electorate, alongside most of the 7,000 others in the construction industry in Spence, you will receive a bigger, better and fairer tax cut under this Labor government. If you are a nurse at the Lyell McEwin or Gawler hospitals, alongside most of the 12,000 individuals working in health care and social assistance in Spence, you will receive a bigger, better and fairer tax cut under this Labor government. If you work in retail, putting hours in at the Elizabeth City Centre alongside the over 8,000 constituents working in that sector in Spence, you will receive a bigger, better and fairer tax cut under this Labor government. If you are a teacher at Munno Para Primary School, as well as the nearly 5,000 others working in education in Spence, you will receive a bigger, better and fairer tax cut under this Labor government. If you work at Service South Australia, like many of the 5,000 people working in the public service in Spence, you will receive a bigger, better, fairer tax cut under this Labor government. And if you are bus driver working in our public transport system for Torrens Transit at Edinburgh North depot, like the other 4½ thousand transport workers in Spence, you will receive a bigger, better and fairer tax cut under this Labor government, and that is because it is a Labor government, an Albanese Labor government, that has the backs of low and middleincome Australia, not those opposite. We are the party of working people—Middle Australia—and we are delivering bigger, better and fairer tax cuts for all of Australia. I commend the Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024 to the House.   One of the things that people really hate about politicians is the fact that all too often they say one thing before an election and do something totally different after it. It creates cynicism and erodes trust in our very system of government. Election commitments, particularly legislated ones, should be kept. Its very disappointing that the government has broken its tax commitment and squibbed an opportunity at real reform of our rates of income tax and bracket creep.  As an Independent, its also important to assess the impact of any taxation changes on the residents of our electorate of Calare. In this regard I have requested and sought a detailed breakdown from Treasury on that impact. The costofliving crisis has taken a huge toll on our young people, our working men and women, our families and our seniors. It has devastated our communities. Its being felt in every aspect of life, from higher grocery prices, power bills, mortgage rates and rents to being hit hard at the bowser by skyhigh petrol prices. Under the changes proposed by the government under the Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024, low and middleincome earners, those earning under $150,000, will be better off. Those earning above $150,000 will still get a tax cut, just not as much as they otherwise would have. The Treasury figures made available to me show that there are tens of thousands of people in the Calare electorate earning between $45,000 and $120,000. All of them will be significantly better off under these changes. In the Bathurst postcode, there are about 12,420 taxpayers who fall into this tax bracket; in the Orange postcode, there are about 13,250; in Lithgow, 3,457 people; and in the Mudgee postcode, 4,334. They will all get significant relief under this legislation. There would be around 8,000 taxpayers earning between $120,000 and $180,000. As I have said, all of those earning under $150,000 will be better off under these changes. The number of taxpayers earning more than $180,000 totals about 3,200 taxpayers. In summary, the Treasury figures reveal that tens of thousands of our local taxpayers, an overwhelming majority, will be better off under these changes and gain important costofliving relief. Because of this fact and the benefit that this measure can deliver to those tens of thousands of our residents, I will be voting in favour of it. As I have said, its very disappointing that the government has broken its promise to the Australian people. It should have found a way to keep its commitments and deliver costofliving relief to low and middleincome earners. That is something that the government will have to answer for at the next election. So many residents of our communities are at breaking point because of costofliving pressures that just never seem to end. Costofliving pressures not only strain household budgets; they can strain relationships too. Costofliving pressures degrade the very standard of living of our communities. The pain is real. Relief is needed. That, to me, is the decisive factor in considering this legislation.  The Albanese government is giving every Australian taxpayer a tax cut. What weve got on the opposite side, though, is a party that wants you to work longer hours for less money in your pocket. While weve heard that they might say theyre going to vote for this tax cut, we know that they have said so many different things about why they hate it. They hate it so much that they just might vote for it!  Im looking forward to watching them vote for it this week, because its good policy, its good for Australia, its good for the economy and its good for families doing it tough—it would just be nice to hear some of those opposite admit it. If you look at the principles that drive this government, they are: noone held back, noone left behind and making sure that Australians earn more and get to keep more of what they earn—something that we stand for every day in this place. I want the 170,000 people who come into the Perth CBD every single day to work to earn more and to keep more of what they earn. As with the rest of Australia, 80 per cent of those taxpayers will get a bigger tax cut under this plan. Weve seen in the words from those opposite a constant approach of opposing things and then asking, Why didnt you do something about it? We saw that when it came to energy bill relief. They opposed energy bill relief and then came into this chamber the next day and asked questions about why we werent doing something about power bills. They opposed cheaper child care and then ran around their electorates asking, Why arent you doing more to help people with child care? They opposed more affordable housing and then wrote letters asking when they were going to get more investment in affordable housing in their electorates. And we saw this week, in the brilliant, brandnew but equally timeless ABC documentary Nemesis, a reminder that those opposite even opposed JobKeeper, until the union movement told them that just maybe supporting workers in the middle of a pandemic would be a good idea. We saw former Treasurer Frydenberg suggest that maybe it was John Howard who told him to do that, but the Australian people know the truth: it was actually the Labor Party and the union movement, out there advocating for ordinary working people. Thats why every day that we come into this place we think, How do you support working Australians? You see it in this legislation: a tax cut for every Australian taxpayer, not leaving anyone behind, making sure that all 13.6 million Australian taxpayers get a tax cut. And, because this plan delivers for every taxpayer in every electorate, every member should vote on it and vote for it this week. We know that an average income earner will now get a tax cut of $29 a week which is more than double what they would have got under the old MorrisonDutton plan. Thats a bigger tax cut for Middle Australia to help with the cost of living, and its responding to the pressures Australia faces here and now. Under this plan more Australians will get a tax cut than under the old tax cuts that were endorsed by the Morrison Dutton cabinet, and 11.5 million Australians will get a bigger tax cut compared with the old plan. This is part of a comprehensive plan for costofliving relief while not adding to inflation, recognising that we can do electricity bill relief, make medicines cheaper, make it easier and cheaper to see a doctor, provide cheaper child care, build more social and affordable homes, provide feefree TAFE, get wages rising to the fastest rate in a decade and give a bigger, fairer tax cut for working Australia. And thats not all! This government delivered the first—
subdebateinfo: Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024, Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living—Medicare Levy) Bill 2024
Speaker: Mr BURNELL (Spence)

name: An honourable member
content: An honourable member interjecting—  Mr GORMAN: No steak knives, but you get the first budget surplus in 15 years—something those opposite promised but could never deliver. But I did notice in Nemesis that they dont mind using the knives on the other side. We talk about every taxpayer getting a tax cut, and I want to talk in detail about what that means for my electorate of Perth—every taxpayer in every suburb. In West Perth an executive assistant at a small mining company earns $75,000 a year and gets a $1,554 tax cut. In Perth a cleaner at the Hyatt hotel gets an $814 tax cut but would have got nothing under the old Liberal plan—not a single dollar. In East Perth a public servant at the Department of Education gets a $1,429 tax cut. In Mount Lawley an operator at the checkout at Fresh Provisions gets a $1,054 tax cut. A librarian in Maylands gets a $1,804 tax cut. In Bayswater a construction worker building the muchawaited PerthMorleyEllenbrook train line for Metronet will receive a $3,379 tax cut from their $130,000 wage. In Embleton, a Bayswater Bunnings parttimer gets $504 in tax cuts, taking the tax on their $35,000 of wages from $3,192 down to $2,688. In Bedford someone working at the Bedford Bowling Club gets a $929 tax cut off their $50,000 taxable income. In Ashfield, a bus driver working for Transperth gets a $1,679 tax cut off their $80,000 income. In Bassendean, an early childhood worker gets a $1,179 tax cut off their $60,000 wage. A primary school teacher at Eden Hill Primary School gets a $1,929 tax cut off their wage. Someone who works full time at Coventry Village Spudshed, which is much loved by my community, gets a $1,304 tax cut off a $65,000 wage. In Inglewood, a shift manager at Woolworths not only gets to keep their job—something that the Leader of the Opposition tried to attack just last month when he said that everyone should boycott Woolworths, which would have forced 200,000 Woolworths workers into unemployment—but also, under our plan, gets a tax cut of $1,554. A police officer who works in Yokine gets a $1,804 tax cut. A flyin flyout worker on $140,000 a year who lives in Manoora gets a $3,729 tax cut. In Coolbinia, a disability worker who does important work at the Ability Centre, supporting vulnerable clients, will receive a tax cut of $1,429. In Mount Hawthorn, a barista at the Mezz will receive a tax cut of $804. A mechanic working in Osborne Park gets a tax cut of $2,679. In Tuart Hill, a family that includes a truck driver on $80,000 a year and a nurse on $90,000 a year gets a combined family tax cut of $3,608. In Dianella, a student studying at Edith Cowan University who works parttime as a bookkeeper gets a $354 tax cut and would have got nothing under the old plan. A senior business lecturer at Leederville TAFE gets a $2,179 tax cut off their $100,000 wage. A musician who lives in Highgate gets a $1,304 tax cut. A City of Stirling gardener working to deliver our governments promised upgrades to Joondanna Reserve will get a tax cut of $1,179 off a $60,000 salary. A kitchenhand at the Rosemount Hotel in North Perth gets a tax cut of $1,034 off $54,200 in earnings a year. A performer at the Fringe World Festival in Northbridge will get a tax cut of $879. Each one of these examples—people in every suburb in my electorate—will get a bigger tax cut. Eighty per cent of people across Western Australia will be better off under this plan, and every WA taxpayer gets a tax cut. I went and stood with some of those who will benefit the most, who were going to get nothing under the old MorrisonDutton plan—sorry, under the old Morrison and Leader of the Opposition plan—but will get a significant change to their income under this plan. I stood with Kaaro Palmer when the Leader of the Opposition was in Perth. The Leader of the Opposition didnt meet with early childhood workers. I talked with them, and she said: I have worked 45 years in the industry. I stand here today with support from my fellow … workers … She said: Id like to thank the Labor Party for the tax deductions that we are about to receive. As early childhood workers, we have always been or have seen ourselves as one of the lowest paid groups in the country. Were expected to educate and care for our very young … So these tax deductions, I know for myself, the rebate that I forwent last year … Its going to go a long way. The daytoday living. The food on my table. Filling up my car. These are the things, the necessities … Thats what an early childhood worker in Perth says. Tenille, another early childhood worker, says, really simply: Im looking forward to the tax cut … Im looking forward to a tax return of approximately 800 dollars this year … Thats $800 more than she would have got. She would have got nothing under the old plan. She said: … it … will help me with car insurance … as well as, schoolbooks and everything. Its a big, big improvement. Emma, who works in aged care, said: … this tax cut is really very good because it helps us a lot. Especially the single parents. You can pay the rates … For myself, I think I probably get 1700 dollars in tax cuts this financial year … It would help us with the … cost of living … Im trying to look after everybody. Its great. Thats what early childhood workers and other care economy workers in my electorate say. But then what do the others say? What is the response from those on the opposition—
subdebateinfo: Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024, Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living—Medicare Levy) Bill 2024
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Chester
content: Mr Chester interjecting—   Order! The member for Gippsland will cease interjecting while the member for Perth gives his address. Mr GORMAN: those opposite, when they are asked: where do they stand on the tax cuts? Id firstly point out that in last weeks viewing it wasnt just Nemesis that was embarrassing for the opposition; it was equally embarrassing to watch the Leader of the Opposition on 7.30, where he couldnt even explain his position on these tax cuts. They put the markers out pretty early. The markers were put out pretty early by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, no less, when she said: We will fight this legislation in the parliament. We dont even know what it will look like. If this is what youre doing—fighting the legislation in the parliament—I dont know what that looks like either, because this is not a fight from those opposite. It is an incredibly embarrassing backflip from those who said just a few days ago—indeed, I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was in Perth when she said, Well fight this legislation in the parliament. Its another example—Ive got many—where you see those opposite in the Liberal Party say one thing in Western Australia and do something completely different when they get back here. We also saw that they said they will roll back these tax cuts. So theyre going to vote for them this week and go to the next election saying that theyre going roll them back. Indeed, when asked by Peter Stefanovic, Will you roll back whatever changes are made? it was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, again, who said: Well, this is our position. This is absolutely our position. When it comes to these tax cuts for Middle Australia, what we hear from the Liberal Party and the National Party is kind of like Ten Things I Hate About You. Theyve got the 10 things they hate about these tax cuts: (1) an egregious error; (2) a betrayal; (3) treachery; (4) absolutely shameful; (5) class warfare; (6) a war on aspiration; (7) divisive; (8) a handful of dollars; (9) a big tax grab; and (10) Marxist economics. They are the 10 things they hate about you, but theyre going vote for them. They actually love these tax cuts! What weve got is an opposition that hates something so much—it is so Marxist; its so divisive; its such class warfare—theyre just going have to vote for it. If youve studied the form of those in the opposition when they were in government, you would know that they do like to say a lot of different things. I always go back to my favourite document, which lists the promises that they made when they came into government. Theres Tony Abbott, leader of the then opposition. He becomes Prime Minister. They promised us this: Our plan will put— Mr Chester: Just on a point of relevance, Id encourage the member to address his comments to the legislation before the House. Hes going back now 10 years to the Abbott government, which is hardly relevant to todays discussion.  I remind the assistant minister to address his remarks regarding the legislation. If he does have a compare and contrast, hell need to make it relevant to the legislation before the House. Mr GORMAN: In the few moments I have left, this legislation delivers lower taxes to 11.5 million Australians. I compare and contrast that with the promise that was made by the then Abbott opposition when they said, Lower taxes. Instead, when they had promised lower taxes, they came into the office, and the first thing they did was raise taxes through the debt levy. The only government to actually come in and raise taxes in recent history was, in fact, that of the now Leader of the Opposition, who sat in the cabinet room as they chose to raise taxes. They then promised that they would start reducing the debt, and we know the trillions of dollars of errors that came as a result of that. (Time expired)

name: Dick, Milton MP
content: Australian families are under pressure. Local community organisations and charities in Cunningham have been helping so many local families—people who are struggling to pay their bills and people who are struggling to get by. I recently visited Bulli Community Centre, which provides help to those in need. There were so many families lining up to receive help from their fortnightly food pantry. I would like to acknowledge the amazing work undertaken by Elizabeth Brassaud, the Manager of Bulli Community Centre, and her hardworking and passionate team of volunteers for their selfless work in support of our community. They relayed to me the pressure that so many people in our community were facing and the expanded services that they were providing.  Just before Christmas last year, my office organised a barbecue for Homeless Hub clients with Mandy Booker and her amazing team, who told me about how they were helping so many more people in our community. Ryan Park, Paul Scully and I joined many of our local Labor volunteers, who came together to provide a barbecue for Homeless Hub clients. I want to take this opportunity to thank all of those Labor Party members who cooked meals and brought them along to the Homeless Hub. While it was only a small contribution, along with dinner we organised free haircuts by the amazing Kevin Crane from Broken Glass Hair and Michelle Alexander—two bright, friendly and incredibly generous people who provided beautiful cuts, styles and a laugh to Homeless Hub clients. A huge thankyou to Grant Logue from Harley and Johns Seafoods, who provided fresh prawns, which were a really huge hit, for our Homeless Hub clients. Renay Horton All Occasions Flowers at Port Kembla brought along some beautiful Christmas bouquets. The team at Illawarra Multicultural Services also provided some lovely desserts. We had so many people there to help out people who are desperately in need of our community. It was a beautiful display of our community coming together to help other people in our local community. For nearly 40 years the Wollongong Homeless Hub has been helping those in greatest need. They have reported an increase in demand for their services. Mandy Booker from the Homeless Hub said the costofliving crisis means theyve seen demand for their services reach a 10year high. Not only is demand for homeless services like Wollongong Homeless Hub increasing; the pressure is impacting the donations and philanthropic support that fill the gap of years of underfunding, resulting in a real risk of program cuts and people being turned away. Before Christmas I also visited the Salvation Army, whose large team of volunteers help to pack hampers and toys for more than 350 families. We also visited the Lighthouse Christian church in Wollongong, which provides a range of services for people who are doing it tough. The stories that I heard from the hardworking staff at all of our local community organisations left no doubt in my mind that we needed to rethink the stage 3 tax cuts. The coalitions tax plan was formulated in 2018, and the world has changed since then, including from the impact of COVID and the war in Ukraine. In my local community it was very clear that action needed to be taken. Around the world, countries are experiencing the same issues of high inflation. Sadly, dealing with the impacts of inflation and the housing crisis was not a priority for the former government. Rises in rent and mortgage repayments have significantly impacted on the discretionary expenditure of low and middleincome households. Many families have been forced to go without and many have struggled to meet their commitments. Our tax reforms deliver real reform to the tax system and real tax relief for all Australians. Under our plan, around 123,000 people in the Illawarra and the Southern Highlands will receive a bigger tax cut than they would have under the coalitions plan from five years ago. In the Cunningham electorate, 84 per cent of people will be better off. By contrast, the opposition argued for higher tax cuts for highincome earners. Labors plan is part of a broad program that is providing relief for all families and individuals by boosting incomes and reducing costs. Lets be clear about this: a person with an income of $100,000 will receive an annual tax cut of $2,179. This is $804 more than under the coalitions plan. A worker who earns the average taxable income of around $73,000 will receive an annual tax cut of $1,504, $804 more than that offered under the coalitions tax plan. A childcare worker on $40,000 will receive a $654 tax cut. How much would they have got under the coalition? Nothing. Importantly, from 1 July, 5.8 million women—80 per cent of taxpaying women—will receive a bigger tax cut. This bill, the Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024, meets the real needs of Australians by increasing the size of their pay packets. What do these changes mean for the Illawarra? They put more money in the pockets of nurses at Wollongong Hospital, more money in the pockets of teachers at our local schools and more money in the pockets of agedcare and childcare workers in Cunningham. All of these workers will benefit more under the Albanese Labor governments tax plan than they would have under the coalitions stage 3 tax cuts.  In accordance with the resolution agreed to earlier today, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. House adjourned at 22:00
subdebateinfo: Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living Tax Cuts) Bill 2024, Treasury Laws Amendment (Cost of Living—Medicare Levy) Bill 2024
Speaker: Ms BYRNES (Cunningham)

name: N/A
content: The barbaric attacks on the people of Israel, on 7 October, shocked and horrified the people of Mackellar. Our hearts broke for the affected families and the people of Israel. The earnest hope and call still is for all hostages to be reunited with their families.  In recent months I have also received an enormous amount of correspondence from people in Mackellar about the humanitarian crisis in Gaza—far more than for any other issue since I was elected. The nearly 1,000 emails from Mackellar constituents expressed deep distress at the ongoing and deteriorating humanitarian crisis in Gaza and horror as the death toll steadily rises, thousands upon thousands. In these letters, constituents implore me to urge our government to use our countrys respected voice to call unambiguously and strongly for a ceasefire, to call for the killing of civilians and children to stop and to call for Israel to ensure that adequate levels of aid reach the people of Gaza to prevent the real risk of more people dying every day from starvation, dehydration and exposure. I worry how often such calls for a ceasefire or criticism of Israels military actions are misconstrued or mislabelled as attacks on Jewish people. They are not. It is humanitarianism, not antisemitism, and no government should be above being held to account. It is possible to hold two truths in your heart at the same time—in this case, a deep concern for the people, and the plight, of Israel and a desperation to see the killing of innocent people and children in Gaza stopped immediately. The preliminary ruling of the International Court of Justice that there is a plausible case of genocide for Israel to answer is extremely grave. So I thank the Albanese government for their repeated assertions that the way Israel defends itself matters. I welcome Australias comments in support of the ICJ—that it plays a critical role in upholding international humanitarian law. I welcomed Australias vote last December in the UN General Assembly calling for a humanitarian ceasefire and an immediate release of hostages. But so much more needs to be done and urgently, particularly as we learn that thousands more are at risk of being killed in Rafah, where tens of thousands have crammed into this small area as the only supposed remaining safe place in Gaza. So I urge the government to again call strongly for an immediate ceasefire, and I urge the government immediately to resume financial support for UNRWA. I urge the government to call Israel to not proceed with its planned military assault in Rafah. I thank all the people who have written to me for not looking the other way. (Time expired)
Speaker: Dr SCAMPS (Mackellar)

name: N/A
content: It is with a heavy heart that I inform the House of the death of a great woman, activist, nurse and friend, Dr Olfat Mahmoud. Dr Mahmoud was a secondgeneration Palestinian refugee. She was a descendant of the Christian and Muslim people who fled their beloved homeland in 1948 to live in the refugee camps in Lebanon after the founding of the State of Israel. Olfat was born in that refugee camp. She faced incredible challenges her whole life. She endured and survived the unfettered violence of Sabra and Shatila in 1982. It was in the aftermath of that that she came into contact with volunteer nurses—Australian Nursing and Midwifery members, actually—who were giving their time and skills to care for the refugees in the camps. These nurses formed the origins of APHEDAUnion Aid Abroad, an organisation auspiced by the ACTU. Its mission is a passionate commitment to global justice, peace and equality.  Another wonderful woman, Dr Helen McHugh, was one of those nurses, and it was her experiences in those refugee camps that ignited a fire in her belly to start APHEDA. Dr Mahmoud saw the care provided by those nurses, especially to women and their children, and she wanted to help—to help her own people. She came to Australia in 1986 on a community nurse training program run by APHEDA. She desperately wanted to take those skills back to Lebanon and care for the Palestinian refugees in her community, and that is exactly what she did. In 1993, Dr Mahmoud established the important Palestinian Womens Humanitarian Organization. After gaining a doctorate in psychology and teaching in this area, she published a book about her refugee story, Tears for Tashiha, in 2018, referring to her familys home town, which she was never permitted to return to. She undertook many speaking tours advocating for the rights of Palestinians. Dr Mahmoud, my dear friend Olfat, showed exceptional leadership, courage and bravery throughout her life, and she will be greatly missed. She died, after a long battle with cancer, on 24 September last year. Olfat would be deeply distressed by the unfettered and abhorrent violence in Gaza. She would agree with the United Nations highest legal body, the ICJ, who found that the situation in Gaza is catastrophic and that Israel should do everything in its power to avoid killing innocent Palestinians, causing them serious bodily or mental harm, creating intolerable living conditions in Gaza or deliberately preventing Palestinian births. In a joint statement with New Zealand, Australias foreign minister noted that the decisions of the ICJ are binding and we do expect Israel to act in accordance with the ICJs ruling, including to enable the provision of basic services and humanitarian assistance. Dr Mahmoud is survived by her husband, four boys and two grandchildren—third and fourthgeneration Palestinian refugees. Vale and rest in peace. (Time expired)
Speaker: Ms KEARNEY (Cooper—Assistant Minister for Health and Aged Care)

name: N/A
content: Its a privilege for me to rise to congratulate all of those in my electorate of Hughes who were honoured in the Australia Day honours list this year. They are: Ms Sheree Bourke OAM of Bonnet Bay, for service to education, including as a science teacher at Menai High School and relieving principal at Tempe High School, and for her work with the school district displays competition and awards at the Sydney Royal Easter Show; and Mrs Rita Taylor OAM of Heathcote, for service to surf lifesaving. Mrs Taylor is a club historian and life member of Garie Surf Life Saving Club, having been involved in the club since 1956. There is also Ms Rebecca Rowan ACM of Engadine, in recognition of distinguished service by an operational member of a civilian corrections service; Ms Rosemary Burke PSM of Sutherland, for outstanding public service in the implementation and running of the COVID19 vaccination program and special health accommodation pharmacy support for the NSW Department of Health; and Mr Graeme Loy PSM of Oyster Bay, for outstanding public service to health care, particularly in the delivery of COVID19 related services and as Chief Executive of Western Sydney Local Health District. Congratulations to all of you. You have all made significant contributions to our community in your individual areas of expertise. While I know that you do not seek recognition, I am delighted to be able to provide that in this place.  I turn now to another major issue in my electorate: the state of Heathcote Road and the decision by the federal government and the federal Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to dump coalition plans to commence the feasibility and planning studies for its duplication. Heathcote Road is 24 kilometres in length. Its a major Sydney artery in the south, connecting Western Sydney to the Sutherland Shire and the Illawarra. Thirtysix thousand people travel on this road every day, going to work, taking children to school and moving building materials to construction sites. For the most part its a singlelane road. People across the electorate continually raise with me Heathcote Roads safety and congestion. Hundreds have signed my online petition. In the leadup to the 2022 election, I helped secure $17.5 million to commence the planning work for the duplication in its entirety. That funding has now been cancelled by Labor, cancelled by the infrastructure minister, with no rational reason why. I also thank Chris OKeefe from radio station 2GB for helping me champion the cause for my local community, many of whom are his listeners. I call upon the Albanese Labor government and federal infrastructure minister, Catherine King, to stop playing politics with the lives of those in the shire, Sydneys south and the southwest. Restore funding for the duplication of Heathcote Road.
subdebateinfo: Hughes Electorate: Australia Day Honours and Awards, Hughes Electorate: Roads
Speaker: Ms WARE (Hughes)

name: N/A
content: The Albanese and the Cook Labor governments are both committed to easing costofliving pressures for our community. Thats why, last week, we introduced legislation that will see every Australian taxpayer receive a tax cut. Its why we are working together to ease energy bills with rebates over summer, meaning more people can afford to use their air conditioning. And it is why, at the beginning of this month, free public transport for students getting to and from school was introduced. The cost of public transport for school students really does add up. The WA Labor government has run the numbers and estimates that families will save more than $500 on getting their kids to and from school thanks to this measure. This will make a massive difference for families in our community. The Albanese Labor government is working with the WA Labor government on our No. 1 priority: easing costofliving pressures.  I want to give a very special shoutout to one of our own: Gosnells local Mitch Wishnowsky, who took to the Super Bowl pitch yesterday as part of the San Francisco 49ers team. Mitch was called into action early in the game, punting the ball some 54 yards—50 metres, for those of us familiar with that. It was helpful that he started out his football career at our local Huntingdale Junior Football Club. He put in a real MVP performance. And, while the outcome was no love story, I am sure hell shake it off. Id like to take this opportunity to pay my respects to my friend Alisdair Putt, who passed away last month undertaking the Worlds Toughest Row competition, rowing across the Atlantic Ocean. His team were taking part in the sixweek challenge to raise money for the Veterans Transition Centre in Western Australia that supports both veterans and their families with respite and transition. He was skippering a fourman rowing team made up of current and former defence personnel when he suffered a medical episode. Alisdair was a pretty amazing person. He was a former intelligence agent, a Navy reserve officer, a former prosecutor and a war crime investigator. I was fortunate enough to work with Alisdair at the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. He was a principal legal officer, well experienced, and I was a freshfaced, new legal officer, but Alisdair was always generous with his time, freeflowing with the anecdotes of his experience both in the law and in many other roles he had performed. In one particular case, where he led me—a massive case for me to work on at such a junior level—he was such a great guide in helping me develop my experience as a prosecutor. Alisdairs funeral was held on Monday, and there was, deservedly, a huge crowd in attendance. My condolences go to his family. Vale, Alisdair Putt. Rest in peace.
subdebateinfo: Western Australia: Cost of Living, Wishnowsky, Mr Mitchell (Mitch), Putt, Mr Alisdair Edward
Speaker: Mr KEOGH (Burt—Minister for Veterans Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel)

name: N/A
content: I rise this afternoon because there is a severe natural disaster occurring in my patch this afternoon. We have catastrophic conditions and fires from the Grampians area, with risks right up to Wyperfeld National Park. For those who live in that region, there is a lot of fear and anxiety. Many have left their homes now, under advice from Vic Emergency. I think its important that, in this House, we keep our feet firmly grounded on why we are here—to stand up for our communities.  These conditions that are currently occurring across Victoria, with high winds up to 80 kilometres an hour, are not expected to abate until later tonight. The risks are high. There are many families who are now homeless. There are dry thunderstorms happening, with lightning strikes which have occurred overnight. Incredibly strangely, a freight train going from Adelaide to Melbourne last night started six fires as it was travelling through my electorate. We in this House cant solve natural disasters, but we can certainly reach out and support and be there to represent our communities, and that is my aim this afternoon. I am thinking of those who live in the beautiful Grampians National Park area, Dadswell Bridge, Pomonal—who have evacuated—Bellfield, Wartook and Roses Gap. Even the Western Highway is now closed between Horsham and Deep Lead, near Stawell. So much of the southern part of Mallee is now in the warning area for fire. Can I urge anyone who happens to be on their social app and sees this: please, be constantly alerted by the emergency.vic.gov.au app and the warnings that are being provided. The ABC, of course, is providing uptodate information as well. I think of the councils and have reached out to them to let me know what can be provided, and Im really pleased to say that the Minister for Emergency Management, Murray Watt, has already reached out with anything that he can provide. This is what we do in this House. This is bipartisan. We want our communities to know that they are loved and they are being watched over.
Speaker: Dr WEBSTER (Mallee)

name: N/A
content: I rise today to address a matter of great concern to my constituents and my local community, and thats the closure of the Glenroy post office. Nearly six months ago, I stood before this very chamber and expressed my shock and dismay, and the shock and dismay felt by the people of Glenroy, at the decision made by Australia Post—without any consultation or transparency—to close the local post office. Since then, all the efforts to reverse the decision have been met with a degree of frustration and, frankly, disappointment.  The Glenroy post office is not just a place of business; its a vital provider of essential services and support for those in our community. Its closure will have farreaching consequences for the people of Glenroy, particularly for the elderly and disabled members of our community. Despite repeated attempts to engage with Australia Post, our concerns have been dismissed and calls for reconsideration have fallen on deaf ears. I wrote in December to Ms Siobhan McKenna, the chair of Australia Post, and I outlined the concerns of my constituents regarding the closure of Glenroy post office; yet, to this day, I have not received a response. The closure of the Glenroy post office is not merely a logistical inconvenience; it is a denial of basic rights and a betrayal of trust. Its a stark reminder of the systemic barriers faced by the most vulnerable members of our community, because Glenroy post office provided access for the elderly and those with disability. It had suitable disability access: it was in a flat location, with a wide entrance and a wheelchair access ramp. Many of the alternative locations which Australia Post has put forward do not meet these standards and do not meet the standards and guidelines outlined in the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, which was, of course, proudly passed under the Paul Keating Labor government. So, without urgent compliance with the act at these alternative sites, the closure of the Glenroy post office has discriminatory effects on the elderly and the disabled community in my electorate. Many of these alternative locations are also, frankly, inaccessible via public transport, which is needed by those community members. Australia Post has also refused to grant a licence to an alternative provider, a newsagent in Glenroy, which is also a deeply disappointing decision because it was an alternative solution. I again publicly ask, as I asked in my letter, that Australia Post reconsider their refusal to grant a licence to the local Glenroy provider. The decision to close Glenroy post office and the subsequent treatment of this issue by Australia Post is, frankly, deeply disappointing. So today I am also urging any colleagues—and this is a bipartisan thing—who have received any constituent concerns to reach out to me so that together we can send a clear message to Australia Post: the needs of our communities must not be ignored.
Speaker: Mr KHALIL (Wills)

name: N/A
content: I rise today to update the House on the status of live animal exports to Israel since the 7 October Hamas invasion and on how Australia continues to deliver an important source of food security to the Middle East. According to LiveCorp, the value of Australias live sheep export trade to the Middle East is $143 million, and it supports around 3,500 regional jobs, mostly in my electorate of OConnor.  In 2023, live sheep exports to Israel were up fourfold on the previous year, and WA live exporters continued to successfully ship consignments to Israel and the broader Middle East. Unfortunately, the voyage of the MV Bahijah has proved an exception, and there must be serious questions asked of the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry as to why this shipment was approved in the first place. While Israeli importer Bassem Dabbah has imported into Israel in the past, it appears nonsensical that the safety of an Israeli consignment via the Red Sea was not questioned by DAFF. I state for the record that noone disputes that the rerouting of the Bahijah away from the threat of Houthi rebel attack near the Red Sea was the safest option to protect human and animal life. But the fact that the contingency discharge destination for the Bahijah was also deemed unsafe only reinforces the poor judgement that DAFF exercised in permitting this illfated voyage. After the exporter voluntarily rerouted the Bahijah towards South Africa on 16 January, DAFF explored the viability of multiple exporter applications to reroute. But, on 20 January, DAFF directed theBahijahto return to Fremantle port, arriving on 29 January 2024. Questions must be asked of DAFF as to why, on arrival in Fremantle in the midst of a heatwave, there was no clear plan for either the offloading or the reshipping of livestock aboard theBahijah. It has recently come to light that DAFF decisionmaking was confounded by the intervention of animal activists. Animals Australia had lodged multiple submissions to DAFF while publicly peddling fake news, posting historical photographs superimposed on land temperatures of up to 41 degrees, fabricating animal suffering that is simply not happening. Only yesterday DAFF reported that the department continues to receive daily updates from the veterinarian aboard the vessel, and the livestock remain in good condition. Meanwhile, in Israel, animal activists are seeking a court injunction to prevent theBahijah from discharging, should it ever reach its desired destination. DAFF have admitted that these actions and uncertainties confounded and delayed their decisionmaking process. Ultimately, DAFF ordered theBahijah to be unloaded, with livestock to be held in a registered liveexport feedlot, pending a final decision. This raises the obvious question of how much suffering animal activists are willing to create in order to achieve their ideological goals of ending not only live animal export but commercial livestock production in general. One thing that has become clear throughout this entireBahijah episode, now clocking up its 39th day, is that our animal welfare standards do work and are leading the world.
Speaker: Mr RICK WILSON (OConnor)

name: N/A
content: I start with the obviously very tragic event in my community over the last six days: the disappearance of Samantha Murphy, a 51yearold mum who is known to many across the community of Ballarat. The police investigation is continuing, and I do want to say thank you very much to VicPol and to the SES, the CFA and council workers as well as the many volunteers across our community who have done all that they can as part of that. I know its an incredibly distressing circumstance for Samanthas family and those who love her.  On 1 February, it was the 40th anniversary of Medicare. Its one of the crowning achievements of federal Labor, and its perhaps one of the most significant social reforms in our nations history. Forty years on, Medicare is as important to Australians today as it was in 1984. On Medicares birthday, I was lucky enough to visit the Ballarat urgent care clinic to celebrate this achievement with the wonderful care staff and the former member for Ballarat, now in his 90s, John Mildren. John was the member while the Medicare legislation was debated, passed and finally implemented as one of the first major reforms of the Hawke government. It was a privilege to hear the stories he had to share about the history of Medicare through that time. What he emphasised was that Medicare was not something that was easy. Its passage was not without controversy and it faced significant resistance from the opposition as well as from doctor groups. But what John told us was why it had to be done. It may seem alien to us today, but John told us of constantly needing to assist constituents, in the same electorate office I am in now, like mums who fell a couple of dollars short of the then very low safety net—you either had the safety net or you could afford private health insurance, and if you were in the middle there was nothing available to you other than paying by private means—who were in absolute distress and tears because they could not afford access to care for their babies. It seems extraordinary today that that was the circumstance faced by MPs such as us. Not only did Medicare give all Australians the care they needed but it gave us our dignity. Im proud to be part of a government now which is just as committed to Medicare today as the Hawke government was then. Im glad that, today, Australians do not face the same barriers to access affordable health care as they did when John was the member for Ballarat. But I also know that we should strive for more. Theres a lot of work to be done, and we cant take affordable health care for granted. Its why were committed to strengthening Medicare, providing better access to cheaper health care, cheaper medicines and affordable hospital treatment. In my electorate of Ballarat, there have been 6,000 extra bulkbilled consultations through October to December. Thats a great achievement, but there is of course always more to be done. (Time expired)
Speaker: Ms CATHERINE KING (Ballarat—Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government)

name: N/A
content: Australia Day is a day to celebrate everything thats great about Australia. We celebrate our fortunate way of life, our values and our freedoms. There is no better way to recognise the people in our electorate of Dawson who hold these values every single day than the 2024 Australia Day Honours List. I rise today to congratulate the four individuals from our electorate who have been awarded these prestigious honours and to pay tribute to their commitment, dedication and service to our community and, indeed, our country. The recipients were Councillor Jan Clifford OAM, Mr Kenneth Martin OAM, Mr Colin Meng OAM and Warrant Officer Benjamin Kilgour CSM.  Councillor Janet Clifford was awarded the Order of Australia Medal for her service to women in local government and to the community of the Whitsundays. My good friend Jan has dedicated 15 years of her life to being a councillor at Whitsunday Regional Council as well as being an active and passionate representative for multiple community organisations such as the Australian Local Government Womens Association, Rotary, the MackayWhitsunday branch of Regional Development Australia, PCYC, the Whitsunday Housing Company—and the list goes on. Mr Kenneth Martin was awarded the Order of Australia Medal for his service to community music. Now a life member, Mr Martin served as President of the Mackay Choral Society for 25 years and vicepresident for 16 years. During this time he was successful in securing grants to maintain their buildings and infrastructure, as well as taking to the stage many times, as he is a talented performer. Mr Colin Meng was awarded the Order of Australia Medal for his service to the community through a range of organisations. Col previously owned two businesses before becoming Mayor of the Mackay Regional Council. He has continued his community involvement while serving on multiple boards such as Mackay Hospital and Health Services and the Mackay Region Chamber of Commerce, just to name a couple. Last, but certainly not least, Warrant Officer Benjamin Kilgour, a fine Australian soldier, was awarded his Conspicuous Service Medal for his achievement as the senior enlisted advisor and operations warrant officer deployed to the headquarters of the Middle East on Operation Accordion from July 2022 to January 2023. The tireless dedication of each of these individuals should serve as inspiration to all of us. They should all be proud of what theyve accomplished. Thank you for your service.
subdebateinfo: Dawson Electorate: Australia Day Honours and Awards
Speaker: Mr WILLCOX (Dawson)

name: N/A
content: In Queanbeyan last Friday I had the immense pleasure of helping to celebrate the achievements of a bunch of fantastic young people, all of whom completed their qualifications in hospitality training with Embrace Disability Group. Congratulations to Tara, Robbie, Jack, Ayden, Bryce, Abbilea and Emily, who have successfully completed their certificate III in hospitality through their traineeships at Jerrabomberra High School.  Embrace Disability Group is really taking the lead in providing opportunities and delivering catering services in the Queanbeyan region while also creating social change. This team of culinary experts working alongside individuals living with disability uses locally sourced produce to craft menus that tantalise the tastebuds and create unforgettable dining experiences. A big congratulations to all the students, and a big thank you to Matt Morrisey, Trish Deveau and the Embrace Disability Group for their commitment to students and for providing them the opportunity for skills development and empowerment. Over the weekend I had the opportunity to again take part in Tumbatrek, a privilege that I now have carrying on as the custodian of Tim Fischers walking stick. Around 150 participants walked through the beauty of the regions landscape, including Paddys River Dam, Reef Creek and Duffers Gully, which is part of the Hume and Hovell track, as we head to the 200th anniversary of the Hume and Hovell expedition. The aim of the trek is to bring together community groups, all levels of government and businesses to talk about many things. We talked about tourism, bushwalking and other business opportunities for the region. I want to give a big shoutout to the years 11 and 12 Tumbarumba High School students who are doing the Kokoda trek and used this as an opportunity for training. Well done to Tumbarumba Rotary, especially Glenn McGrath, Grant Harris and Bruce Wright, for all you do in making those students ready for that trek. I recently wrote a letter of support for a remarkable community member, and it struck me that she deserves much more recognition for the work that she is doing. Zita Vafiopulous started a group called Snowy Valleys Heroes which is committed to preserving the memories of our Snowy veterans. Zita and the group have spent the past 14 months researching veterans from across the Snowy Valleys for inclusion in the first book, called Snowy Valleys Heroes Book 1 18501920. They now have 3,603 veterans comprehensive information on the men who enlisted from the region. The team have shown tremendous dedication in their quest to preserve the memories of Snowy veterans, and I congratulate Zita for all of her work. Finally, I want to make a quick acknowledgement of and to thank the amazing Mrs Pearce. Mary Pearce has been teaching in our public schools for 50 years. Mrs Pearce, you are so loved, you are so knowledgeable and we are incredibly grateful for the impact youve had on so many families. The DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mrs Andrews ): In accordance with standing order 193, the time for members constituency statements has concluded.
subdebateinfo: EdenMonaro Electorate: Community Events, Vafiopulous, Ms Zita, Pearce, Mrs Mary
